Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 20th Annual IEEE International Symposium on High Performance Computer Architecture (HPCA 2014)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award supports the attendance of students to the 20th Annual IEEE International Symposium on High Performance Computer Architecture (HPCA 2014), to be hosted on February 15-19th, 2014 in Orlando, Florida. The HPCA Symposium, a top-tier conference on computer architecture related research, has enjoyed a rich history of success. The research results presented at HPCA conferences have shown strong impacts in this research field and are highly regarded among the computer architecture community. Students have much to gain from attending HPCA such as learning state-of-the-art methodologies, being exposed to novel techniques, and interacting with senior researchers in their chosen area of expertise.

The importance of formal verification is becoming widely accepted. Increasing the attendance of students in HPCA will expose more students to the exciting developments in the field and in the long run will help to build a broad base of expertise in the field, which will impact both industry and academia.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
We received $15,000 to support travel grants for graduate students who attended HPCA 2014. We awarded this money to 45 full-time students, for an average of $333 per student. The award amounts were determined by a mix of merit (e.g., presenting author in main conference, workshop/tutorial presenter, or attendee) and need (as demonstrated by both the raw costs for each student and whether their faculty advisor wrote a letter of support indicating that they could not provide funds). We were able to support all the students who applied for a grant (except those who withdrew later).

The actual award amount given to each student was determined based on the following priorities: (1) Conference presenters, (2) workshop presenters, and (3) Conference attendees. For category (1), we paid $450 for each. For category (2), we supported $290 for each. For category (3), we gave $160 for each due to the limited funds. We have 26 conference presenters (category 1), 2 workshop presenters, and 17 attendees received the award. Finally, all students who applied for the grants have been awarded. 

The US NSF funds all have been awarded to students from US-based universities. Meanwhile, IEEE TCCA also supported up to $7000 which was awarded to students from non-US-based universities. The rate for each category is the same as the students from US-based universities.
